title: What is the history of the oldest building in your town? - Quora

response.answer_text: I live in Pavia, in Italy, where the oldest constructions are actually underground, and they are the old Roman sewer network, over 2,000 years old. They criss-cross the city in a grid pattern, and most of them still effectively carry rain-water down to the river Ticino today. In the 14th century, a local historian writing a Latin book about the city, said that some of the sewers are so big that it’s possible to ride down them on horseback. In the 20th century, a university student named Carlamaria Tomaselli decided to see if this was true, and with her hard hat on she went down into the ancient tunnels, Indian Jones style, and found it really was the truth. Today you can see a section of sewer in the market beneath the main square of town.

We have a Dutch colonial farm house awarded to Baron Von Steuben after the Revolution. It was owned by a Tory who fled lynch mobs. The Dutch colonized Upper New Jersey and Manhattan. We still have Dutch families, French Huguenot and the Jackson Whites, a tri racial tribe of Ramapough Natives. They used to speak a Dutch Creole.
